APS Stechkin
The Stechkin APS is a Russian selective fire machine pistol, bearing the name of its designer Igor Stechkin. Originally chambered for 7.62x25mm Tokarev, the pistol was changed to use 9x18mm as it became clear that this cartridge was set to become the new service ammunition for handguns in the Soviet Army. In 1951, the Stechkin was introduced into the Soviet military arsenal, replacing the aging TT-33.

Colt M1911
Designed by John Browning, the M1911 is an extremely reliable and robust pistol that remained the standard-issue side arm of the US military from 1911 to 1985. To this day, it remains very popular for military, police and civilian use around the world.

FN Five-seveN
A delayed blowback, semi-automatic pistol designed as a complimentary sidearm for the FN P90 submachine gun as they both share the same 5.7x28mm cartridge. This allows the Five-seveN to provide good penetration against targets protected by body armor while keeping the weapon's weight, dimensions and recoil reasonable.

Glock 17 "Bruder"
A classic polymer-framed, short recoil-operated pistol trusted by law enforcement officers and military personnel around the globe because of its unsurpassed reliability, optimal magazine capacity and low weight. The Glock 17 is easy to operate and maintain and is a versatile weapon that can be used for self-defense, target shooting, or combat situations. The "Bruder" has been equipped with an integrated base for sight installation, a tactical rubber grip and a threaded barrel among various intermal modifications.

Korth Custom 4
A custom pistol made by the legendary, high-end firearms manufacturer, Korth. For some gun aficionados, nothing more needs to be said. Korth weapons are perhaps best known for having price tags that most people would find easier to associate with German cars than German guns, though the entry point is far more accessible. Simply put, Korth guns are legendary.

A Russian recoil-operated, locked-breech, semi-automatic pistol, using a modified Browning cam-lock system adapted from the Browning Hi-Power pistol. Built for police and military use, the PL-15's key focus was on ergonomics and safety.

A Russian recoil-operated, locked-breech, semi-automatic pistol, using a modified Browning cam-lock system adapted from the Browning Hi-Power pistol. Makarov PM
This Soviet legacy is one of the best compact self-defence handguns available. Small, highly reliable, easy to use and easy to maintain, the Pistol Makarova was selected because of its simplicity, easy manufacturing, accuracy and reasonable stopping power. Unfortunately though, it loses out to modern pistols in its class in terms of weight, magazine size and general performance.

This Soviet legacy is one of the best compact self-defence handguns available. Small, highly reliable, easy to use and easy to maintain, the Pistol Makarova was selected because of its simplicity, easy manufacturing, accuracy and reasonable stopping power. Unfortunately though, it loses out to modern pistols in its class in terms of weight, magazine size and general performance. The Custom includes a threaded barrel and tritium iron sights.

Makarov PM "Mythic"
This Soviet legacy is one of the best compact self-defence handguns available. Small, highly reliable, easy to use and easy to maintain, the Pistol Makarova was selected because of its simplicity, easy manufacturing, accuracy and reasonable stopping power. Unfortunately though, it loses out to modern pistols in its class in terms of weight, magazine size and general performance. Some say this pistol was manufactured as a limited run of PMs. Others say its a handcrafted upgrade. Regardless of the truth, it is a fine weapon and comes with a pre-threaded barrel for easy suppressor installation.

Makarov PMM
A redesign of the legendary Makarov, the PMM uses a 25% increase in gas pressure to significantly increase muzzle velocity and features a larger 12-round magazine while keeping the same simplicity, ease of manufacturing and accuracy of the PM. Though, even with these changes slightly bridging the gap between itself and modern pistols, it still loses out in terms of weight and general performance. This model features a threaded barrel.

PB
PB
The PB (Pistolet Besshumnyj or Silent Pistol) was developed in 1967 for Spetsnaz units of the Soviet Army and KGB operatives. The pistol is based on a modified Makarov PM and features a unique integrated two-part suppressor that reduces bullet velocity to below subsonic levels.

Serdyukov SR1M Gyurza
A semi-automatic pistol designed as an analogue of the famous Italian Beretta for the Russian military. However, the constructors decided to make their upcoming creation more powerful and effective in close combat. The result surpassed their greatest expectations, as the newly arrived SR-1 Gyurza was immediately adopted by the Federal Protective Services.

KS-12
A semi-automatic shotgun made in the U.S.A. but based on Russia’s popular line of Saiga hunting shotguns. The long stroke gas system of the legendary AK-47 is carried over to the KS-12 and provides reliable operation under extreme environmental conditions. This model includes a trigger mechanism which allows for two-round bursts.

KS-23
At its core, the KS-23 is a manually-actuated, pump-action "shotgun" that fires unique 23mm shells. Though, while displaying an appearance more akin to a shotgun, the Russians designated the KS-23 as a "Special Carbine" due to its large-caliber rifled 700mm barrel when compared to the standard smoothbore barrels of conventional shotguns.

AK-12 "Monolith"
The standard service assault rifle of the Russian army, designed to replace older AK-74M and AK-100 series rifles. This model is the pinnacle of AK system development, different from the previous generations by its elaborate ergonomics, all-day usability and increased accuracy and precision. Capable of a hyperburst fire mode. This model is rarely encountered and is often found in the hands of the Monolith. It features an extended magazine and vertical foregrip for increased stability.

AK-74
Developed in the early 1970s by Mikhail Kalashnikov to replace the AKM, the AK-74 is an adaptation of the 7.62x39mm AKM assault rifle and features several important design improvements including the use of the newer, high velocity 5.45x39mm round. Compared with the preceding AKM, it has better effective firing range, accuracy and reliability.

AS Val
Engineered for Soviet special operations units, the AS Val is a gas operated, integrally suppressed weapon that was set to supersede the AK-47 and AKM rifles. It is easily disassembled and concealed, lightweight and comfortable to fire with the suppressor reducing bullet velocity to below subsonic levels. Today, the AS VAL sees widespread use among Russian special forces.

FN SCAR-H
In early 2004, USSOCOM issued a design request for a family of assault rifles using two different calibers while keeping the parts and ergonomics nearly-identical; hence the Special Operations Forces Combat Assault Rifle "SCAR" was born into service. M4A1
The M4 Carbine descends from a family of firearms tracing its lineage back to the original AR-15 by ArmaLite. It is a gas operated, air cooled, selective fire rifle, sharing 80% of its parts with the M16 assault rifle, though it is notably shorter and lighter. It has been adopted by United States Special Operations Command (USSOCOM) and is the preferred weapon of the U.S. Army Special Forces and Navy SEALs. The A1 variant strengthened the barrel and replaced the burst-fire fire select with a fully automatic option.

Ruger SR-556
A semi-automatic, piston-driven, gas-operated AR-15 style rifle. Lightweight and ergonomic, Ruger wanted to minimize the sharp impulse of the piston striking the bolt carrier typically found in short-stroke ARs, and instead used a two-stage design in which the piston delivers two smaller impulses to the operating rod instead. This design choice allows the weapon to be easier to handle and more accurate during sustained fire. Capable of a hyperburst fire mode.
